body_text.text: The novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) represents a public health emergency of 31 international concern [1] . As of 10rd March 2020, the death toll from the novel 32 coronavirus stood at 4,012, with more than 113,702 confirmed cases in China, as well Table 1 ). The SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan genome presented 708 75 UUU ssRNA fragments, which represents 17.4% more fragments than the SARS-CoV 76 genome (1.17-fold change) and 8.1% more than the MERS-CoV genome (1.08-fold 77 change). No difference was found in the number of UUU ssRNA fragments between the 78 SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan genome and the SARS-CoV-2/Germany genome isolated on 79 January 28, 2020 in Germany (only two additional sequences) ( Table 1 and Fig. 1) . 80

Interestingly, (UUU) 2 repeated motifs were more abundant in the SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan 81 and SARS-CoV-2/Germany genomes (n=4) than in the SARS-CoV genome (n=2) and 82 equally represented in the MERS-CoV genome ( Table 1 and Fig 1) . 83

The SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan genome presented 518 UUC ssRNA fragments, which was 84 less than the number in the SARS-CoV genome (n=563). However, (UUC) 2 repeated 85 motifs were 13.6% more abundant in the SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan genome than in the 86 SARS-CoV genome (1.15-fold change) ( Table 1 and Fig. 1) . 87

Regarding UUA/G ssRNA fragments, show a lower binding affinity than the other motifs 88 to TLR7, we found 27.1% (UUA; 1.27-fold change) and 5.3% (UUG; 1.05-fold change) 89 more ssRNA fragments in the SARS-CoV-2 genome than in the SARS-CoV genome. No 90 notable differences were found in the number of these ssRNA fragments between the 91 SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan and SARS-Cov-2/Germany genomes (Table 1 and Fig. 1) . However, the number of UUG ssRNA fragments was higher in the SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan 99 genome than in the SARS-CoV genome, as previously shown in the TLR7 analysis 100 (Table 1 and Fig. 1) . 101
Therefore, it can be speculated that the SARS-CoV-2 genome contains more ssRNA 102 fragments with the possibility of interacting with TLR7/8 than the SARS-CoV genome. 103

Accordingly, SARS-CoV-2 has many more chances than SARS-CoV to contact the host 104 innate immune system, and SARS-CoV-2 has the similar probability than MERS-CoV to 105 interact with TLR7/8. In conclusion, the SARS-CoV-2 genome contains more ssRNA fragments that could be 158 recognized by TLR7/8 than the SARS-CoV genome and similar ssRNA fragments than 159 the MERS-CoV genome; possibly making it able to provoke a robust proinflammatory 160 response via TLR7/8 recognition and cause acute lung injury, leading to death. These 161 bioinformatic findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 plays a crucial role in the overactive 162 innate immune response. 163

Coronaviruses are single, positive-sense RNA 34 viruses belonging to the family Coronaviridae, which includes Middle East respiratory 35 syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 36 (SARS-CoV) [3]. 37 Viral interactions with the host immune system play a central role in the outcome of 38 infection. In the initial phase, recognition of evolutionarily conserved microbial structures, 39 known as pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), is an essential function of 40 the innate immune system [4]. Germ line-encoded pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) 41 are proteins expressed by a variety of cells and are responsible for sensing the 42 presence of PAMPs. Sensing of PAMPs by PRRs markedly upregulates the 43 transcription of genes involved in inflammatory responses. [4]. 44 Toll-like receptors (TLRs) belong to a conserved family of innate immune recognition 45 receptors acting as the primary sensors of specific PAMPs expressed by numerous 46 pathogens [5]. The human TLR family comprises 11 members, of which TLR-3, -7, and -47 8 are essential in recognition of structural components of RNA viruses [6-8]. TLR7 48 senses single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) oligonucleotides containing guanosine-and 49 uridine-rich sequences from RNA viruses [6]. Recognition occurs in the endosomes of 50 plasmacytoid dendritic cells (DCs) and B cells. TLR8 is phylogenetically and functionally DCs and monocytes [7]. 53 In this study, we searched ssRNA fragments in the whole genome from SARS-CoV, 54 MERS-CoV, and SARS-CoV-2 (from different geographical origins mainly from Germany 55 [SARS-CoV-2/Germany] and Wuhan [SARS-CoV-2/Wuhan]) by a bioinformatics 56 scanning technique to reveal important TLR7/8 recognition sites in the whole genome of 57 these. 58 2. FIGREF3.text: SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV, and MERS-CoV infections show several similarities 108 regarding the clinical presentations, which can vary from asymptomatic infection to 109 severe disease [13]. Additionally, a cytokine-storm has been observed in the rapid 110 course of SARS [14, 15] and MERS [16, 17], and in the serum of SARS-CoV-2-infected 111 patients, proinflammatory cytokines are upregulated [18]. It was inferred that an 112 overactive innate immune response could contribute to virus-induced immune pathology 113 resulting in acute lung injury in the infected patients. Therefore, in this study, based on 114 the essential structural feature of the PAMP-PRR complex, specifically the interaction of 115 TLR7/TLR8 with ssRNA [11, 12], we searched ssRNA fragments with a pathogenic 116 molecular pattern from the SARS-CoV-2, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV whole genomes. 117 Our bioinformatic analysis showed that the SARS-CoV-2 genome contains a large 118 number of fragments that could be recognized by TLR7/8, and it even contains more type I interferon response [7]. The production of type I IFNs (primarily alpha IFN [IFN-α] 121 and IFN-β) plays a central role in the induction of antiviral responses. Type I IFNs 122 influence protein synthesis, growth regulation, and apoptosis and enhance the 123 maturation of DCs, the cytotoxicity of natural killer cells, and the differentiation of virus-124 specific cytotoxic T lymphocytes [19]. However, innate immune hyperactivation could be 125 involved in the dysregulation of a series of proinflammatory cytokines during viral 126 infection [20]. 127 The recognition of ssRNA fragments by TLR7/8 could depend on the virus replication 128 manner, so that a more robust proinflammatory response should occur after a latent 129 period, except for the host immune cell taking up viral particles. This effect is feasible 130 because a number of immune cells display distinct susceptibility to MERS-CoV [17] and 131 SARS-CoV [21]. 132 Interestingly, in addition to its expression in immunological cells, TLR7/8 is expressed 133 predominantly in the lung, bronchus, breast, rectum, smooth muscle tissue, cerebral 134 cortex, and kidney [22]. Although TLR7 and TLR8 are phylogenetically and structurally 135 related, TLR7-and TLR8-specific agonists trigger different cytokine induction profiles. 136 TLR7-specific agonists generally induce IFN-regulated cytokines, but TLR8-specific 137 agonists lead primarily to the production of proinflammatory cytokines [23]. These 138 factors may provide SARS-CoV-2 with a shortcut to trigger an innate immune response 139 through TLR7/8 and ultimately contribute to the development of immune pathology 140 within the lungs. 141 immune receptors, such as SARS-CoV spike protein, which was observed to be a TLR2 143 ligand [24], and damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) that are released in 144 response to tissue damage from cells killed by viruses [25]. All of these factors also 145 probably contribute to the cytokine storm. The interaction between viral PAMPs and 146 PRRs in immune cells plays an essential survival role in the response to viral infections 147 but may be simultaneously responsible for tissue injury associated with severe virus-148 induced inflammation. 149 For positive-sense RNA viruses such as coronavirus, it is known that viral genomic 150 ssRNA is recognized by either the endosomal RNA receptors (TLR7/TLR8), and the 151 cytosolic RNA sensors, such as retinoid-inducible gene-1 (RIG1), melanoma 152 differentiation-associated gene 5 (MDA5), laboratory of genetics and physiology 2 153 (LGP2), and cytoplasmic protein kinase R (PKR) [26]. Nevertheless, the consensus 154 definition of cytosolic RNA sensor ligands remains controversial, and the crystal 155 structures with their RNA sequence-specific are not available. For this reason, the 156 cytosolic sensors were not included in the bioinformatic analysis. 157
